title: X Factor's Dean Ray says he almost took his own life as he struggled with 'anxiety and depression'
text:
Dean Ray scored a lucrative deal with Sony Music after he was declared the runner-up on The X Factor Australia in 2014.

But on Tuesday, the singer revealed he almost took his own life while heavily promoting his debut single Coming Back shortly after his stint on the show.

Speaking to The Daily Telegraph, Dean said he was struggling with anxiety and depression and the media interviews were 'too much for him' in late 2014.

'I wanted to stop it': The X Factor's Dean Ray (pictured) said he almost took his own life as he struggled with 'anxiety and depression' after the show in 2014 on Tuesday

'When I got back to the hotel room that night in Sydney, a panic attack hit me and I wanted to stop it. When you pair anxiety with depression, your mind tells you "this is how you fix it" and I tried to get out of the windows but they were (sealed) shut,' Dean said.

'I fell to the floor and cried like a two-year-old, I couldn't stop shaking.'

The singer said he told his management that he wasn't feeling well enough to do the media rounds in the morning, but did not go into the severity of his condition.

Concerning: Dean said he was suffering from anxiety and depression when he had a panic attack, triggering suicidal thoughts after a day of interviews. He is pictured on The X Factor

Shortly after, Dean parted ways with Sony Music, but has since released a second album with Franklin Sound Art in 2017.

His distressing reveal comes ahead of an appearance on ABC show The Show Must Go On, which is about the shocking rates of suicide in the entertainment world.

The singer announced his involvement in the documentary on Instagram, in hopes it will 'spark much needed conversations about mental health'.

'While this film may not reach and save every life, we hope it will have enough impact to at least save one,' Dean wrote.

Good work: Dean has become a mental health advocate, recently playing at Walk for Awareness. He is set to appear in a documentary The Show Must Go On about suicide rates in the entertainment industry

Former Home and Away star Ben Steel is making the documentary along with appearances from Sam Neill, Michala Banas and David McAlliste.

Dean still tours across the country and recently played a string of shows throughout Queensland including a gig at Walk for Awareness about mental health.

If you or anyone you know is struggling, call Lifeline 13 11 14.
